API Reference¶

Environment¶

The Environment class is the central class of the program, because all other functionalities are called and synchronized via this class. When creating an environment instance, the corresponding data that is to be represented by this instance must be passed directly. This process data passed during initialization is stored in an internal format and automatically provided to the corresponding method when various functions are called.

class environment.Environment¶

An execution Environment for the event based production simulation. The entire process to be mapped is defined in the transferred files and the structure must comply with certain rules.

data_to_csv(path_to_wd: str, components: List[str], remove_column: Optional[List[str]] = None, keep_original: bool = False, remove_name: bool = True) → None¶

Creates csv files of the values stored in the process. If the passed path is not valid, it will be created in order not to lose the simulation data.

Parameters

  • path_to_wd (str) – Path to the working directory where the .csv files should be saved

  • components (Tuple[str, ..]) – Components for which data files should be created.

  • remove_column (Tuple[str, ..], optional) – Columns, which are removed if they are present

  • keep_original (bool, optional) – If columns are removed the original is kept in an extra file

  • remove_name (bool, optional) – Remove the name, because it is the same for all entries

inspect() → None¶

Checks the given data for possible errors that do not lead to an exception when generating the internal data formats, but would lead to a crash during the simulation. The corresponding errors are systematically output. This function should not be called at the same time as the simulation, since the errors are not corrected by this method, but only indicated and thus the simulation crashes nevertheless. Thus this method is to be seen as a help to free new data sets before the simulation from errors.

Raises

MissingData – Either no data was read in or the data read in does not contain ‘item’ and ‘station’

plot_attr_over_station(path_to_dir: str, attr_name: str, *args: List[Any], x_label: Optional[List[str]] = None)¶

This method plots already saved simulation data from .csv files. The generated graph can contain several box-plots. Each box plot describes the expression of exactly one attribute at one station across all stations.

Parameters

  • path_to_dir (str) – Path to the directory where the png. file should be saved.

  • attr_name (str) – Name of the attribute whose value is to be displayed in the graph.

  • args (List[Any]) – Lists the data set and the station where the data is to be taken.

  • x_label (List[str], optional) – Names of the stations that are plotted on the x-axis.

Raises

  • FileNotFound – The passed path was not found

  • InvalidValue – The attribute to be tracked does not exist in the passed file

  • ToManyArguments – An attempt is made to plot more than 4 data series

  • InvalidFormat – One of the data lists does not have the length two

plot_attr_over_time(path_to_dir: str, attr_name: str, *args: List[Any])¶

This method plots already saved simulation data from .csv files. The generated graph can contain several plots. Each plot represents the course of a specific attribute over time at an arbitrary station.

Parameters

  • path_to_dir (str) – Path to the directory where the png. file should be saved.

  • attr_name (str) – Name of the attribute whose value is to be displayed in the graph.

  • args (List[Any]) – Lists the data set and the station where the data is to be taken.

Raises

  • FileNotFound – The passed path was not found

  • InvalidValue – The attribute to be tracked does not exist in the passed file

  • InvalidFormat – A list element of args doesn’t have length three

  • MissingAttribute – Passed process step does not occur in the passed file.

read_files(data_file: str, function_file: str) → None¶

This method converts the data from the input files passed by the user into an internal data format which is used for further operations.

Parameters

  • data_file (str) – Path to the json-file with the process data

  • function_file (str) – Path to the py-file with the function definitions

Raises

  • FileNotFoundError – No matching files could be found for the given file paths

  • MissingParameter – The attribute ‘item’ or ‘station’ was not defined in the process file or an item or station object has no defined name

  • UndefinedFunction – One of the referenced functions could not be found in the function file

  • UndefinedObject – One of the referenced item or station could not be found in the data file

  • InvalidType – The component list has an element which is not of type list or the capacity of an item or station isn’t of type int

  • InvalidValue – The capacity of a item or station isn’T greater than zero

  • NotSupportedParameter – One of the values of user defined attributes has an undefined identifier

run_simulation(sim_time: int, track_components: Optional[List[str]] = None, track_comp_on_station: Optional[List[str]] = None, progress_bar: bool = False) → None¶

This method starts the actual simulation. It should be checked in advance with the methods ‘inspect’ and ‘visualize’ whether the entered data is set correctly.

Parameters

  • sim_time (int) – Simulated time

  • track_components (List[str], optional) – Components whose process data is to be stored

  • track_comp_on_station (List[str], optional) – Stations on which the process data are stored for each item

  • progress_bar (bool, optional) – Specifies whether a progress bar should be displayed

Raises

MissingData – Either no data was read in or the data read in does not contain ‘item’ and ‘station’

visualize() → None¶

This method is used to visualize the input process data by creating an interactive network graph of the input process data. It shows both the material flow and the item and station specific parameters. This method initiates a local development app on a flask server on localhoast:8050. For an example see example 02.

Raises

MissingData – Either no data was read in or the data read in does not contain ‘item’ and ‘station’
